text:
SARA MURRAY: President
Trump's chief strategist

getting a very public
slap on the wrist,

Donald Trump declining to
throw his full confidence

behind Steve Bannon
in an interview

with the "New York Post,"
saying, "Steve is a good guy.

But I told them to straighten
it out, or I will"--

those comments coming just days
after tensions between Bannon

and Trump's son-in-law and
senior adviser, Jared Kushner,

reached a boiling
point, prompting Trump

to tell the two
of them on Friday
to iron out their differences.

While the White
House is publicly
downplaying staff spats--

SEAN SPICER: A lot
of it is overblown,
what you see in the media.

SARA MURRAY: --a source
familiar with the situation

says the president was irked
by suggestions that Bannon
is the one driving the agenda.

As Trump's allies noted, top
staffers could better serve
the president by laying low.

CHRIS CHRISTIE: Staff are
there to serve the president
of the United States.

They're not there
to serve themselves.

SARA MURRAY: In the "New
York Post" interview,

Trump downplayed the role
of his own chief strategist,
saying, "I like Steve.

But you have to remember he
was not involved in my campaign
until very late.

I had already beaten all the
senators and all the governors,
and I didn't know Steve.

I'm my own strategist,
and it wasn't

like I was going to change
strategies because I
was facing crooked Hillary."

But Trump's attempt to
diminish Bannon as a latecomer

to the campaign hardly
meshes with reality.

The former head of the
right-wing nationalist

"Brietbart News" website
was one of Trump's

prominent cheerleaders,
pointing out

at a conservative
conference this year

that "Brietbart" took notice
of Trump's appeal early on.

STEVE BANNON: It's really
CPAC that have-- have really

originally gave him
the springboard.

It's the first time,
at "Brietbart,"
we started seeing him and see--

saw how people-- you know, his
speeches resonated with people.

SARA MURRAY: In the early
days of the Trump White House,

Bannon's influence steadily
expanded, eventually landing

him on the cover of "Time"
magazine, which dubbed
Bannon "The Great Manipulator."
- Send in Steve Bannon.
[music playing]

SARA MURRAY: His
perceived importance

was famously lampooned
on "Saturday Night Live."
- OK, Donald.
That's enough fun for tonight.
Can I have my desk back?
- Yes.
Of course, Mr. President.
I'll go sit at my desk, yeah.
[laughter and applause]

SARA MURRAY: Now the ball
appears to be in Bannon's court

to mend relationships
within the White House

and keep a low profile,
at least for now.

Republicans close
to the White House

warned it will be a
heavy lift for Bannon

to repair his standing
after taking on a member
of Trump's own family.

Now, Bannon is still a
conservative media darling.

And the danger in kicking
him outside the White House

is you could see these
right-wing websites turn
their knives on the West Wing.

We may have seen an early
inkling of that today

when the "Washington
Free Beacon," which

is a conservative website,
took aim at civil war
within the White House.

But their knives were
out for Jared Kushner,

saying he's meddling too
far in national security.
